text: the key to thriving in today's knowledge
industry isn't just what knowledge you
know but how wisely you can apply it
I've spent the past decade studying the
value of wisdom and in my recent hbr
article I show how moving beyond a focus
on knowledge work and embracing wisdom
work helps teams to be more productive
improves employee retention and creates
a more Innovative work environment so
what is wisdom the difference between
knowledge and wisdom is that you
accumulate knowledge and you distill
wisdom knowledge can be something that
you could find on Google or you know
chat gbt but wisdom is hard one it's
sort of the School of Hard Knocks it's
often something that you've experienced
in your life and then metabolize that
experience as a lesson and then it
becomes part of how you see the world
moving forward I gained a lot of these
insights when in 2013 the millennial
founders of Airbnb asked me to help them
democratize Hospitality what was
particularly interesting is a month
after I was there working with Brian
Brian pulled me aside and said I hired
you for your knowledge but what you
really brought is your wisdom wisdom is
often something that's common sense for
you but maybe not for someone else and
especially as you get older there are
things that at age 52 I thought were
absolutely obvious but they were not
obvious to people who are half my age I
cover all this and give you four tips
for how to put wisdom to work in your
workplace in my article go to hbr.org
for more
